channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Daily Mail charity flies in PPE for NHS
item.description: New charity Mail Force has brought 20 tons of vital coveralls and masks - worth over £1 million - fresh from China. The packages are destined to help NHS tackle a dire shortage of equipment.
item.media:credit: Jamie Wiseman and Mark Large for The Daily Mail

item.title: More Americans killed by COVID-19 in three months than in the entire Vietnam War
item.description: Coronavirus deaths in the United States reached to 58,233 on Tuesday night, meaning more Americans have died of coronavirus than casualties suffered by the U.S. in Vietnam between 1955 and 1975.

item.title: Swiss grandparents are told it's SAFE to hug grandchildren if they are under ten
item.description: Pictured: A mother with her young daughter meet her grandparents for a drink across the Swiss-French border in Sezegnin, closed by a concrete block, near Geneva on April 16.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Woman with PPE stockpile won't donate to NHS
item.description: Becca Brown, from Portsmouth, shelled out thousands for PPE as NHS trusts across the UK battled to secure the equipment needed by medics to treat coronavirus patients.

item.title: Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty becomes artists' muse
item.description: Professor Chris Whitty has been a household name ever since the coronavirus outbreak took its hold on Britain last month.

item.title: Royal Navy nuclear submarine commander John Lewis is SACKED after coronavirus lockdown barbecue
item.description: Commander Lewis has been relieved of command of HMS Trenchant and will be assigned other duties after a Royal Navy investigation into the gathering.

item.title: Ivanka is back! First daughter returns from self-quarantining at her father's golf course
item.description: Ivanka Trump appeared with her father at an East Room small business event, and was again credited by the president for creating millions of jobs.

item.title: Row as paediatricians express 'anger' at NHS alert on 'coronavirus links' to inflammation disease
item.description: Lewis Greig, from Torry, Aberdeen, has been on a ventilator at the Royal Hospital for Children, Glasgow, after he suddenly became unwell last week with a high temperature.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Is government altering lockdown 'five tests'?
item.description: Slides displayed at the daily Downing Street briefing held by Matt Hancock showed that it is now saying there must be no second peak 'that overwhelms the NHS'.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... the coronavirus death toll
item.description: Rate of London Covid-19 deaths set to exceed the Blitz

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Puffed-up baker Paul doesn't do wry... unless it's in a loaf of bread
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Let's Fishing Enjoy is the incoherent slogan of a restaurant called Zauo in Tokyo, where diners scoop fat bream or flounder from a shallow pond.

item.title: Will masks in public finally get the go-ahead?
item.description: Michael Gove revealed that a Treasury minister is leading a 'domestic effort' to ensure that enough face coverings are available should the Government change its guidance.

item.title: Boeing 737 MAX is 'expected to remain grounded until at least August due to software issues'
item.description: Boeing Co's grounded 737 MAX jet is expected to remain grounded until at least August as the manufacturer continues to grapple with software issues, people briefed on the matter told Reuters.

item.title: Duchess of Cornwall reveals how she starts her day with ballet lessons and a 'little bit of pilates'
item.description: Camilla, 72, who is in Scotland with Prince Charles, let slip her secret love of ballet in a video call to mark International Dance Day with Darcey Bussell, and Angela Rippon.

item.title: SARAH VINE: We must not let the coronavirus crisis rob us of our humanity
item.description: SARAH VINE: Sunday was a very sad day for us. The mother of a dear friend passed away in hospital from Covid-19.

item.title: M&S defies pressure to cut executive pay packages
item.description: Chief exec Steve Rowe (pictured) will still take his full £810,000 salary plus bonuses this year despite asking long-suffering savers and the taxpayer to prop up the ailing business.

item.title: Doctors group claims that hydroxychloroquine helps 91% of coronavirus patients
item.description: The Association of American Physicians and Surgeons (AAPS) claimed that 91.6% of coronavirus patients treated with hydroxychloroquine fared better - but they cite many anecdotal reports.

item.title: Private schools could reopen before state ones because they have more distancing space, say experts
item.description: Independent schools will find it easier to introduce pupils back after the coronavirus lockdown as they have space in newer facilities, the former chair of a body representing public schools has said.

item.title: Coronavirus can more easily multiply in 'stiff' lung tissue seen in the elderly
item.description: A new review article, from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, finds that mucosal cells are 'stiffer' in older patients due to more protein fibers, allowing coronavirus to multiply more easily.

item.title: Matt Hancock dismisses speculation some parts of the UK could see lockdown eased before others
item.description: The Health Secretary said curbs would almost certainly be lifted across the country in harmony, dampening speculation that some parts of the nation could have restrictions eased first.

item.title: Final section of new Genoa bridge slots into place two years after 43 were killed when it collapsed
item.description: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte stood beneath the gleaming structure on Tuesday and declared: 'today a new light shines on Italy.'

item.title: Matt Hancock announces expansion of coronavirus testing regime
item.description: Matt Hancock today announced coronavirus testing eligibility is being extended to include all over-65s and workers who cannot work from home - but only if they have symptoms.

item.title: The largest ozone hole ever seen above the Arctic has closed again just weeks after being announced
item.description: The largest ozone hole ever documented above the North Pole has closed almost as quickly as it formed, after unusually warm spring temperatures heated air in the polar vortex.

item.title: Whitehall inquiry CLEARS Priti Patel of bullying staff
item.description: Sir Mark Sedwill's report found 'no evidence' to corroborate the allegations made by staff at the Home Office, the Department for Work and Pensions and the Department for International Trade.

item.title: A job for the old bill! Police officers escort family of geese along a main road
item.description: An officer from Hampshire police shared this sweet video of a family of geese being escorted to safety as they waddled underneath a bridge.

item.title: Inside Joe Exotic's seedy sex den where jailed zoo owner would film sex videos
item.description: Joe Exotic's seedy sex den sits abandoned after his employees trashed it while celebrating his departure from the zoo, exclusive DailyMailTV photos show.

item.title: Lithuania's capital is turned into vast open air café to enable social distancing in restaurants
item.description: Lithuania's capital city Vilnius is turning into a massive outdoor cafe. The city has offered 18 locations where cafes and restaurants can lay extra tables in a bid to keep the businesses alive.

item.title: Vince Vaughn steps out in LA with no mask or gloves and socializes with friends
item.description: Actor Vince Vaughn was spotted with his six-year-old son Vernon in Manhattan Beach, California, on Friday, without PPE and interacting with friends.

item.title: Quarter pound shrew can bear the weight of a man thanks to its unique interlocking backbones
item.description: A US study that scanned the shrew's super-strong spines has shown that they can support considerable force from spine-to-tail.

item.title: Love Island receives highest number of applications despite summer series in doubt amid COVID-19
item.description: Love Island has reportedly received its highest number of applications yet, while the UK is in lockdown and show bosses are hoping to snap up new reality stars by holding virtual auditions.

item.title: Mother who asked question at Downing Street briefing says Matt Hancock 'evaded' her question
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Sadie Stainfield, 35, from Northampton, pressed the Health Secretary for plans to send vulnerable pupils back to school once classes resume.

item.title: Amazing optical illusion at New Zealand beach shows cruise ship appearing to hover over the horizon
item.description: The footage filmed from a beach at Mount Maunganui in New Zealand showed the vessel seemingly suspended above the ocean last week.

item.title: Mum shares sneaky trick for getting kids to eat more vegetables - and healthy sausage roll recipe
item.description: An Australian mother-of-two has shared her sneaky trick for getting her fussy kids to eat more vegetables without them even realising - and it leaves her kids saying it's their 'favourite meal'.

item.title: Coronavirus crisis in UK could result in 18,000 more cancer deaths in the next year
item.description: The number of deaths in newly diagnosed cancer cases is predicted to rise by a fifth in England alone, causing at least 6,270 extra deaths above what's 'normal'.

item.title: Bournemouth Airport will become the first UK airport to check passengers for signs of coronavirus
item.description: Bosses at Bournemouth Airport have installed 'thermal fever detection' cameras that are capable of recording body temperatures and alerting border guards to anyone with a fever.

item.title: Matt Hancock announces coronavirus drug has progressed in human trials
item.description: Matt Hancock announced in this afternoon's briefing at Downing Street that six drugs are being trialled in the fight against coronavirus - including one that is being tested on patients.

item.title: Nine in ten nurses are feeling more stressed and anxious than usual due to the coronavirus crisis
item.description: A survey asked NHS nurses to rate their overall mental health and wellbeing right now, and 33 per cent described it as 'bad' or 'very bad'.

item.title: Queen will address nation at 9pm on May 8 for 75th VE Day anniversary
item.description: As part of the revised plans to mark the 75th VE Day anniversary during the coronavirus lockdown announced today, Her Majesty's words will be broadcast on May 8 on BBC One at 9pm.

item.title: Britain's £4.2bn foreign gender equality budget must be managed better, says National Audit Office
item.description: Foreign aid chiefs have been told to improve how they manage the £4.2billion being spent on boosting gender equality overseas. In the past £4million has been spent on Yegna, Ethiopa's answer to the Spice Girls.
item.media:credit: © Jamie Wiseman for The Daily Mail

item.title: We're the new romantics!
item.description: Descendants of Mary and Percy Shelley, Lord Byron and William Wordsworth were photographed in celebration of their forebears - and their own accomplishments as the 'New Romantics'.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: British Airways to make up to 12,000 redundant
item.description: Up to a quarter of British Airways' 45,000 workers could lose their jobs as its owners IAG announced mass redundancies on Tuesday afternoon. Owners IAG blamed the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Professor RUSSELL VINER says it's 'incredibly unlikely' there's a new Covid-19 strain targeting kids
item.description: PROFESSOR RUSSELL VINER: 'In the youngest age groups, deaths associated with this coronavirus are rare and there is very good evidence worldwide that they are the part of the population least affected'

item.title: ASK TONY: ASK TONY: £186 vanished after online store account was hacked
item.description: The homewares website Wayfair emailed to inform me my account details, including had been changed. I tried to check my account but my password had been changed.

item.title: The £7bn refund rip-off: Holiday plans are in ruins
item.description: Hundreds of readers have contacted us to complain major airlines are illegally withholding refunds that should be paid in a week. Many say they have been goaded into accepting credit-note vouchers.

item.title: Our 60-year wait for a £50,000 Premium Bond win
item.description: Last month retired school site manager Ken Medlycott (pictured with wife Sally) won a huge £50,000 - doubling his savings. The odds of him winning such a prize in a year were one-in-7,466.

item.title: Gigi Hadid, 25, is '20 weeks pregnant'
item.description: The Vogue cover girl showed a hint of baby bump as she posed with Zayn this week on her 25th birthday while in self-isolation with her family at their farm in Pennsylvania.

item.title: Who makes YOUR lockdown top ten? A team of top writers wrestle with this thorny social dilemma
item.description: As the Government prepares to ease lockdown restrictions, one idea is to allow us to choose ten friends with whom we could socialise.

item.title: When Dr Tedi Millward, who has died aged 89, taught Prince Charles Welsh, it formed a lifelong bond
item.description: 'Firebrand Nationalist' Dr 'Tedi' Millward, who taught Prince Charles Welsh before he became the Prince of Wales (R), has died aged 89. Their friendship was depicted in Netflix's 'The Crown' (L).

item.title: NOAA says 2020 is likely to be the hottest year ever recorded, despite coronavirus pollution decline
item.description: A new report from the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says there is a 75 percent chance that 2020 will be the hottest year in recorded history.

item.title: Supermarket chaos: Needy families STILL unable to get deliveries
item.description: Around 300 of your letters and emails have been pulled together into a damning dossier which we will send to all major supermarkets and a parliamentary inquiry into food supply.

item.title: Experts say coronavirus anxiety is causing vivid dreams and ruining proper sleep
item.description: Professors have collected dream samples from around the world showing the psychological effects of the coronavirus pandemic are transcending culture, language and national boundaries.

item.title: DAILY MAIL COMMENT: Failure to protect valiant NHS staff is a tragedy. Now we can ALL do our bit
item.description: DAILY MAIL COMMENT: The primary role of the free Press has always been to hold power to account. To fight injustice and to ask searching questions of the rich and powerful.

item.title: Arthritis drug trial may only help the most critically iil coronavirus patients
item.description: Results of a study on rheumatoid arthritis drug Kevzara had virtually no effect on 'severely ill' coronavirus patients, but it did help 'critically ill,' meaning they were on mechanical ventilation.

item.title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Cotswolds hideaway favoured by Prince Harry pitches for more punters
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Soho Farmhouse, the £1,650-a-year very exclusive private members' club set in 120 Oxfordshire acres is opening its doors to an army of tent dwellers.

item.title: Dr. Fauci warns the US will be in for a 'bad fall' if coronavirus treatments do not work soon
item.description: Speaking in an interview with The Economic Club of Washington, D.C, Fauci said that it was 'inevitable' it was going to come back and that it might never fully dissipate.

item.title: Police swarm beach after bones foun at Swalecliffe Beach near Herne Bay Kent
item.description: At least eight police cars were scrambled to Swalecliffe Beach near Herne Bay at 7pm today.

item.title: New fast-track breast cancer treatment takes just FIVE DAYS instead of the standard three weeks
item.description: A NHS trial reveals a five-day course of radiotherapy is just as good as the standard three-week treatment. Hospitals are already using the fast-track regime as it reduces coronavirus exposure.

item.title: Covid-19 will not be eradicated and will return become a seasonal virus, Chinese scientists predict
item.description: A group of Chinese viral and medical researchers told reporters in Beijing on Monday that Covid-19 will likely not disappear like SARS did because it can infect asymptomatic carriers.

item.title: Mike Pence tours the Mayo Clinic and DOES NOT wear a mask despite policy
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence flouted the Mayo Clinic's face mask policy when he visited doctors and patients the Minnesota hospital, not wearing the protective covering despite the hospital requirement.

item.title: Andy Warhol had string of male lovers but was 'lousy' in bed
item.description: Andy Warhol was not asexual but had a string of male lovers, a major new biography Warhol by Blake Gopnik reveals.

item.title: Britain's youngest lottery winner Jane Park shares a glimpse inside her lockdown home
item.description: Jane Park, 24, from Edinburgh, scooped £1M back in 2013, shared a glimpse at her life in lockdown, as she keeps herself entertained by glamorous selfies and enjoying her sleek home.

item.title: Woman reveals incredible transformation of the mange-ridden dog she nursed back to health
item.description: Lauren Buckley, 27, from Jackson, Tennessee, took to Facebook on April 18 to open up about her foster dog Lainey's incredible transformation.

item.title: Police launch murder investigation after body of 88-year-old man is discovered
item.description: Surrey Police is searching for a suspected killer after finding the body of an 88-year-old Dennis Kellond in Godstone and officers were seen searching for evidence into the night on the A25 last night.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 21,731 but could be 55% higher
item.description: Weekly data from the Office for National Statistics shows thousands of people are dying of COVID-19 in care homes but not being included in the Government's death toll.

item.title: Foreign Office officials failed to inform police that Harry Dunn 'killer' would be returning to US
item.description: Anne Sacoolas was granted diplomatic immunity and fled Britain after the car she was driving allegedly collided with Harry's motorbike in Northamptonshire last year.
item.media:credit: Jamie Wiseman for The Daily Mail

item.title: Naive clergyman is sacked after parishioner claimed film clip showed him cheating on his wife
item.description: Rev William Bulloch (pictured), 51, has been sacked after he failed to disclose the extent of his friendship with a parishioner who claimed he was cheating on his wife with her.

item.title: Olivia Munn SLAMS disgraced director Bryan Singer saying he went MISSING
item.description: On Tuesday, Munn claimed in an interview to Variety that Singer went missing on the set for ten days because he had a 'thyroid issue' and had to fly back to Los Angeles to get treated.

item.title: Chinese state media insult Australia as diplomatic relations crumble amid coronavirus crisis
item.description: Australia is standing firm in its calls for an independent probe into the origins of COVID-19. China has dismissed any potential investigations, describing the proposal as a 'political manoeuvre'.

item.title: Italy sees total coronavirus cases top 200,000 while death toll passes 27,000
item.description: Italy's total number of confirmed coronavirus cases, which includes those who have died and those who have recovered, has hit 201,505 after an increase of 2,091 today.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Some John Lewis stores to shut permanently
item.description: The UK High Street giant was forced to close all 35 of its department stores and 15 smaller John Lewis At Home shops when Britain went into lockdown in March.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Tourist spots to be shut 'for some time to come'
item.description: Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove told MPs today that 'at the moment and for some time to come' people should not travel to visit popular resorts such as Cornwall.

item.title: Hillary Clinton endorses Joe Biden
item.description: Hillary Clinton endorsed Joe Biden's campaign for president on Tuesday, appearing alongside the presumptive Democratic nominee on a livestreamed event.

item.title: Heartbroken mother tells of moment she found stabbed son, three, and daughter, one, dying on the bed
item.description: EXCLUSIVE - The mother of two youngsters stabbed to death in Ilford, East London, on Sunday says she found their suspected killer kneeling over them with a 'crazed look in his eye'.

item.title: Hayes murder investigation launched after Baljit Singh, 37, was found strangled to death in alleyway
item.description: Police are searching for two people after Baljit Singh, 37, was found dead in an alleyway in Station Road, Hayes at the weekend. DCI Helen Rance said Mr Singh was subjected to a 'vicious assault' and strangled.

item.title: Support worker, 40, suffers a cardiac arrest and dies of coronavirus 18 days after being intubated
item.description: Healthcare support worker Julias Sana, 40, suffered from a fever after working at a private hospital that cared for people with neurodegenerative diseases in Newport, South Wales.

item.title: Steph McGovern HALTS new Channel 4 talk show and declares 'my family need our home back'
item.description: Steph McGovern has announced her Channel 4 talk show will go on hiatus amid the coronavirus lockdown, amid claims the decision to broadcast from her Harrogate home infuriated neighbours.

item.title: UK rejects the contact-tracing app proposed by Apple and Google
item.description: NHSX has chosen not to use Apple and Google´s special joint approach and is instead creating its own centralised app, despite privacy concerns.

item.title: Premier League football set to return by June 13
item.description: Sportsmail understands at least two top-flight clubs have told their employees that there is now a loose aim for the first set of fixtures after the coronavirus delay to take place on June 6.

item.title: RSPCA has dealt with more than 21,000 animal cruelty cases since coronavirus lockdown
item.description: The RSPCA is being called out every two minutes to help abandoned animals during the coronavirus lockdown. Among the abandoned pets were three rabbits in Essex.

item.title: Christopher Reeve's son Will appears on GMA with no pants during at-home broadcast
item.description: ABC reporter Will Reeve, 27, filmed a segment for GMA at home on Tuesday during which he talked about using drones to deliver prescriptions.

item.title: Prince Harry records message for Thomas the Tank Engine
item.description: Prince Harry recorded a special message which has a storyline that includes his father and grandmother, Prince Charles and the Queen, as animated characters.

item.title: Hedgehogs are getting more RANDY thanks to coronavirus crisis say experts
item.description: Less traffic on the roads means hedgehogs are feeling the love and multiplying, an expert from Nottinghamshire has claimed. Michael Walker told the BBC hedgehogs are now 'extremely active'.

item.title: The world's loneliest tree sits on a remote New Zealand island 137 miles away from nearest companion
item.description: The Sitka spruce, on Campbell Island - 500 miles from New Zealand's South Island - has been recognised as the world's most remote tree by Guinness World Records.

item.title: Coronavirus: Bundesliga restart in doubt with Germany gearing up to TIGHTEN lockdown after new cases
item.description: Clubs in the German top flight have returned to training in the hope that the rest of the season can be finished off - providing Chancellor Angela Merkel gives the green light for action to resume.

item.title: Stoke dog owner's missing miniature pinscher Citos was handed in to kennels and sold for £200
item.description: Evita Fadina left her dog with her father in Stoke for a few weeks when moving and returned to find Citos had been sold for £200 and rehomed by Acorn Kennels, Whitchurch, after he ran away.

item.title: Thug, 29, who knocked out officer and beat police dog with plank of wood is jailed for four years
item.description: Nelson Nelson flew into a rage at Nottingham train station on Saturday, April 4 when officers asked him if he needed to be travelling. Jennie Ellse and her dog were among those attacked.

item.title: David Gomoh, 24, collapsed on his doorstep Canning Town east London after stabbing
item.description: Hospital worker David Gomoh (pictured), 24, was fatally wounded in a knife attack on Sunday, seconds after leaving his home in Canning Town, east London.

item.title: Millionaire, 20, gets reality check by posing as homeless man
item.description: Self-made currenct trading millionaire Dan Legg, 20, from Somerset, spent three nights sleeping rough on the streets of London for Rich Kids Go Homeless, which airs on 5Star tomorrow night.

item.title: Kate Middleton has 'matured enchantingly' and showing 'humour and compassion' on recent appearances
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge, 38, had once 'seemed shy' when speaking publicly but has a 'new spontaneity' on recent appearances, Richard Fitzwilliam told the Express.co.uk

item.title: Senior FSB officer becomes the highest-ranked Russian official linked to investigation into MH17
item.description: Col. Gen. Andrei Burlaka, the FSB Border Service's chief of operational staff, has been named as the highest-ranking person of interest in the investigation into the downing of the plane.

item.title: Anorexic who hid stones in her trousers to hide weight loss said exercise saved her life
item.description: Talia Bentley, 23, from Lancaster, was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa aged 16 and spent four years restricting her calorie intake to as little as 500 a day - meaning even 'the smallest' clothes didn't fit.

item.title: Cuckoo named Carlton II sets record by flying 4,677 miles from Africa to England in seven days
item.description: The bird named Carlton II (pictured) was helped by strong southerly winds as sped 4,677 miles from the Ivory Coast in West Africa to marshes in the East of England.

item.title: Oxford University cuts ties to fossil fuel industry
item.description: Vice-chancellor Louise Richardson said Oxford had to take up the mantle of 'reducing carbon emissions and tackling climate change before it is too late.'

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Children may die from Kawasaki-like illness
item.description: Mr Hancock admitted on LBC Radio this morning Britain had 'lost some children' to a disease 'we think is caused by the coronavirus'. He said scientists were probing the illness's link to COVID-19.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Woman on 'inflammatory syndrome' of son, 2
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Bertie Brown was admitted to Worcestershire Royal hospital last month on his second birthday, when his temperature soared over 40C (104F) and his Itchy rash began to turn black.

item.title: Imaging tech reveals secrets of Vermeer´s Girl with a Pearl Earring
item.description: Imaging technology has revealed secret details in the 17th century painting 'Girl with a Pearl Earring' by Johannes Vermeer, including eyelashes and a faint green curtain.

item.title: Exposure to loud noises 'can lead to DNA damage, high blood pressure and cancer'
item.description: German researchers observed mice exposed to loud noises, such as those from a passing aircraft. Four days of aircraft noise led to high blood pressure.

item.title: Does tough application make it almost IMPOSSIBLE to join Land Army?
item.description: Applicants claim to have faced a wall of bureaucracy which saw one company director from West Yorkshire turn down two job offers because they were both five-hour drives away.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Ex-WHO adviser says lockdown should ease in May
item.description: Professor Karol Sikora, a cancer specialist, has warned that thousands of people could die from the disease and heart issues if the lockdown continues for much longer.

item.title: Doctor spared jail for hit and run after telling judge he hoped to work at Nightingale hospitals
item.description: Doctor Ali Shah, 40, from Birmingham, (pictured left) drove at the victim and knocked him off his feet with his wing mirror when he 'saw red'. He drove off without checking if the elderly man was injured.

item.title: Norwegian businessman worth £156million arrested on suspicion of killing his wife
item.description: Tom Hagen, 70, estimated to be worth £156million, was arrested on his way to work on Tuesday morning in Norway. He is accused of murdering his wife when she vanished from their home in October 2018.

item.title: BMW driver rams into a man and crushes him against a wall in a neighbour row in Halifax
item.description: Shocking footage shows a man hit by the car before a fight erupts in Halifax yesterday. More than 12 men threaten others with some carrying weapons and bats requiring police to intervene.

item.title: My Feet Are Killing Me! Man with 'cauliflower feet' asks the doctor to consider amputation
item.description: Jeff Ortega, 30, from lorida, who suffers from Proteus Syndrome - a condition characterized by the overgrowth of the bones and skin, will feature in TLC's My Feet Are Killing Me.

item.title: How to make Wagamama katsu curry: company reveals recipe
item.description: The popular pan-Asian chain, which closed its doors around the UK last month due to the coronavirus lockdown, is now sharing recipes on Instagram, so fans can recreate them at home.

item.title: Microsoft Word will now mark two spaces between sentences as an error
item.description: The new rule is being rolled out slowly across Word, meaning that users may not encounter the new warning until they update their software.

item.title: US scrambles spy planes to monitor North Korea amid Kim Jong Un death rumours
item.description: The South's unification minister Kim Yeon-chul told lawmakers that 'the government is aware of Kim Jong Un's location,' without explaining further.

item.title: Britain sees new record for coal-free power generation
item.description: The previous British record set in June last year was broken at 6.10am on Tuesday morning amid lockdown and high levels of renewables.

item.title: The stunning bike path in Belgium that leaves cyclists feeling like they're riding through water
item.description: The trail scythes through one of the 1,000 ponds in the beautiful De Wijers wetland area in the 550-hectare Bokrijk nature park near Genk, in Belgium's Limburg province.

item.title: Experts baffled by India's lower coronavirus death rate
item.description: India's median age of 28 is well below that in the US (38), Britain (41), Spain (43) or Italy (45), an advantage against a virus which is most dangerous to the elderly.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 20,735 with 360 new fatalities
item.description: The preliminary figure - not yet confirmed by the Department of Health, which releases an official UK tally each day - would be the lowest daily death count since March 30.
